repnme.cdata!:
St. Kitts and Nevis - OECS Education
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The OECS Education Development Project
            for Saint Kitts and Nevis had a moderately satisfactory
            outcome and a substantial risk to development outcome. The
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory and the
            borrower's performance was satisfactory. The main
            lessons learned were: (1) Results framework with a clear
            link between outputs and outcomes. The link between
            Project's activities and the outcome indicators was not
            clearly addressed in the project document. As a result,
            these indicators could not adequately measure the project
            achievements. To maintain the focus on Project Development
            Objectives (PDO) during the implementation and to clearly
            address how different activities and components fit
            together, creating a well-defined results framework is
            critical. (2) Consistent monitoring of indicators throughout
            the project. During the project implementation, not all the
            PDO indicators were included in the Implementation Status
            and Results Report and the data was not updated regularly.
            In addition, the data criteria seemed to be inconsistent.
            This has made the project assessment difficult. (3)
            Realistic cost estimate and scope of work. The Project
            experienced significant cost overrun. This led to the
            reduction of scope of the activities, which caused
            additional delays. The activities should not be included
            unless their funding is assured. The project teams should
            ensure that funding is assured for all the planned
            activities based on a realistic cost estimate. (4)
            Infrastructure maintenance scheme put upfront. (5)
            Continuity from preparation to implementation. The Project
            Advisory Committee was set up to guide the whole process of
            the Project, from preparation to implementation. (6)
            Communication within the Bank. There were some cases that
            the Bank's advice to the Government varied depending on
            the individual officers. The mixed messages from the Bank
            caused some confusion and frustration in the project team
            and affected implementation. It is important that the
            Bank's advice to the client is consistent regardless of
            the personnel who process a client's request. (7)
            Balance between sub-regional approach and targeted approach.
            When setting up regional institutions or initiatives, clear
            arrangements for staffing and sustainability should be
            agreed upfront.

repnme.cdata!:
Organization of Eastern Caribbean States
            (OECS) - Education Development Project (St. Kitts and Nevis,
            and St. Lucia)

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall program objective of the
            OECS Education Development Project is to build human capital
            in the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) which
            in turn will contribute to the diversification of their
            economy and more sustainable growth. St. Lucia and St. Kitts
            and Nevis are the first of the OECS countries to join the
            program. There are three main project components. The first
            increases equitable access and equity in secondary
            education, particularly in poor rural communities, by
            constructing a new secondary school in St. Kitts and
            providing equipment, furniture, and materials; and expanding
            the school meals program in secondary schools. The second
            component comprises 4 subcomponents, which 1) develop
            curriculum for Forms i-III and provide instructional guides,
            textbooks, ad other resource materials; train
            trainers/educators in select areas, including fellowships,
            and development of a coordinated teacher appraisal system;
            2) establish learning resource centers, and expand and
            upgrade learning centers, including science and information
            technology labs; 3) elaborate program to support
            participation of disadvantaged students, and related teacher
            development in special education; and, 4) provide
            school-based improvement projects, and extra-curricular
            activities. The third component expands the education
            management information system, including networking of
            schools and EMIS training.

repnme.cdata!:
Organization of Eastern Caribbean States
            (OECS) - Education Development Project : St. Kitts and Nevis
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental impact assessment
            (EIA) addresses the biophysical, and socioeconomic impacts
            resulting from the project implementation, and, it includes
            reviews of existing site data, and present resource uses,
            identifying as well environmental features, or ecosystems
            requiring attention, and/or protection. The site for school
            construction is presently occupied by two large farming
            plots, and the Ministry of Agriculture have agreed to
            relocate farmers to appropriate sites, of equally
            accessible, and comparable plots, based on communications
            among all parties involved. The site is located adjacent to
            a steep sided ghaut, thus the development has made
            provisions for a 100 feet buffer zone, and mitigation
            includes placing dust screens around the area, particularly
            close to the Housing development, and playing field;
            materials, and surfaces will be water sprayed, while a
            phased removal of vegetation should prevent large areas
            becoming exposed to erosion. In addition, rainwater off the
            various buildings, will be collected into cisterns to serve
            as reserves in times of drought, while a proper sewage
            system will be designed, to incorporate the
            development's future demands, taking into consideration
            the present drilling plans of the Water Department, and the
            need to prevent groundwater contamination. However,
            percolation tests will be required to inform due process. An
            adequate drainage system should be designed to prevent
            occurrence of erosion on the site, during and after construction.
